metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Zhangye wetland station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Zhangye wetland station from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (100.4464° E, 38.9751° N) was located on a wetland (reed surface) in Zhangye National Wetland Park, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed profile (03002; 5 and 10 m, north), wind direction profile (03002; 10 m, north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2 and -0.4 m), and four photosynthetically active radiation (PQS-1; two above the plants, 6 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward; two below the plants, 0.25 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm and Ts_40 cm) (℃), on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2019-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What are the key components and measurements involved in setting up an automatic weather station in a wetland environment for meteorological observations?
Definition.Answer: An automatic weather station in a wetland environment typically includes sensors for measuring air temperature and relative humidity at different heights, a barometer for air pressure, a rain gauge for precipitation, anemometers for wind speed, a wind vane for wind direction, radiometers for four-component radiation, infrared thermometers for surface radiation temperature, soil temperature probes at various depths, soil heat flux plates, and photosynthetically active radiation sensors above and within the canopy. It is essential to ensure data quality through steps like ensuring a fixed number of data points per day, marking missing data, removing duplicates, and filtering out physically implausible values.

Definition.Question: What challenges are commonly faced when collecting long-term environmental data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Long-term environmental data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems faces challenges such as ecological degradation due to drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are prevalent in arid inland river basins, impacting the stability of ecological and socioeconomic systems and necessitating robust data collection and management strategies.

Definition.Question: How can hydrometeorological data and ancillary information about vegetation and soil parameters contribute to understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Definition.Answer: Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture, combined with vegetation and soil parameters, provide a comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems. This integrated data helps recognize interactions within these systems, supporting ecological stability, carbon balance, and sustainable development efforts.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality control measures between datasets collected from the oasis–desert ecosystems and those from the wetland meteorological stations?
Comparison.Answer: Data quality control in oasis–desert ecosystems involves data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing steps, ensuring data reliability over long-term observations. In wetland meteorological stations, quality control ensures each day has 144 data points, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicates, and flagging questionable data in red. Both settings emphasize the importance of data accuracy and consistency, though the specific techniques and focus areas may differ.

Comparison.Question: How does the hydrometeorological data collection in the oasis–desert systems compare to that in wetland meteorological stations in terms of instrumentation and data types?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis–desert systems, hydrometeorological data collection includes radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, often supplemented by groundwater data. Wetland meteorological stations focus on similar data types, but also include specific instrumentation for soil temperature and heat flux monitoring at various depths. Both systems aim to capture comprehensive environmental data, but the emphasis and specific instruments may vary according to the ecosystem characteristics.

Interpretation.Question: How might the data collection method using different sensor heights and orientations impact the interpretation of meteorological phenomena in the Zhangye Wetland?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection method using different sensor heights and orientations allows for a comprehensive assessment of vertical profiles and directional influences on meteorological phenomena. This setup helps in understanding the distribution and dynamics of air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and radiation, which are crucial for interpreting boundary layer processes and local climatic conditions in the Zhangye Wetland.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring data quality and consistency when collecting long-term hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential challenges include dealing with harsh environmental conditions that can affect sensor performance, handling data gaps due to equipment failure or maintenance, and ensuring uniformity in data processing and quality control procedures. These challenges necessitate rigorous data validation and correction protocols to maintain the reliability and consistency of long-term hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert areas.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data loss or errors during the collection of meteorological data can occur due to factors such as harsh environmental conditions leading to sensor malfunctions, the complexity of data processing and quality control procedures, and the challenges of maintaining consistent data collection over long periods. In addition, missing data may be indicated with specific markers, and duplicate or physically implausible data are removed to ensure quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems for sustainable development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial because it helps achieve carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals. It is significant for maintaining ecological stability and supporting the sustainable socioeconomic development of oases, which are vital for the population and economic activities in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in maintaining ecological stability in inland river basins of arid and semiarid regions, and how does this impact data collection efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in maintaining ecological stability in inland river basins arise from issues such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification intensification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental crises can complicate data collection efforts by affecting the reliability of instruments and the ability to collect consistent, long-term observational data.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing long-term observational datasets enhances the quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of various hydrometeorological parameters in data collection affect the analysis of ecological challenges in arid inland river basins?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of various hydrometeorological parameters allows for a comprehensive analysis of ecological challenges, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and land desertification, thereby providing critical insights into maintaining ecological balance and addressing environmental crises in arid inland river basins.

Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing the interactions between these ecosystems. This understanding supports the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, as well as the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish a comprehensive observational network in the Heihe River Basin for monitoring oasis-desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Establishing a comprehensive observational network in the Heihe River Basin is important to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is critical for sustainable oasis development. This network helps in understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, supporting ecological security and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of using high-frequency data collection methods, such as eddy covariance systems, in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes of using high-frequency data collection methods like eddy covariance systems are to acquire detailed and accurate data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. This data is essential for understanding the interactions within oasis-desert systems and addressing the ecological challenges posed by climate change and human activities in arid and semiarid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the detailed steps involved in the data processing and quality control procedure for hydrometeorological data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure is divided into data collection, processing, and data archiving and sharing. This involves ensuring the completeness and accuracy of the data, removing erroneous or duplicate entries, and using standard formats for date and time. Additionally, data of dubious quality is flagged for review.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the eddy covariance system and scintillometer be utilized to acquire long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The eddy covariance system and scintillometer are used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. These instruments measure the exchange of energy, water vapor, and carbon between the land surface and the atmosphere, providing crucial data for understanding ecosystem interactions in oasis–desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to ensure the quality and consistency of meteorological observations across multiple stations in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological observations are standardized by ensuring that each station follows a consistent methodology for data collection, such as using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute averaging period. Quality control measures include verifying the data for physical plausibility, marking missing data, and maintaining consistent measurement setups across the stations.

Enablement.Question: What observational techniques enable comprehensive monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Observational techniques include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, alongside automatic weather stations that provide hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity, with a 10-minute average period.

Enablement.Answer: Necessary conditions and technological setups include the strategic placement of land surface flux and meteorological stations to cover critical regions, using equipment like automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data collection, and ensuring the instrumentation is capable of measuring variables like air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, with additional data on vegetation and soil parameters.

Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, which can affect data consistency and quality.

Long-term observations are indispensable for achieving these goals.

Expectation.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters is critical to comprehensively understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods using automatic weather stations involve acquiring data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and gradients of air temperature and humidity with a 10-minute average period. Enhancements could include increasing the frequency of data collection, integrating additional sensing technologies, or improving sensor calibration and maintenance protocols to ensure accuracy and reduce data loss or anomalies.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the long-term accuracy and reliability of datasets collected from oasis–desert systems, and how could these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term dataset accuracy include ecological environment degradation such as drying rivers and desertification, which may impact sensor stability and data continuity. Addressing these challenges could involve implementing robust data quality control procedures, regular equipment maintenance, and integrating data from multiple sources to verify and validate observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used for ensuring the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedures for meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations include ensuring data completeness with a specific number of data points per day (e.g., 144 data points every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a placeholder, removing duplicate records, discarding data that exceeds physical or instrumental limits, highlighting suspicious data, and using consistent date and time formats.
